In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Recent flagship publications of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and ADB Institute on 
regional cooperation have highlighted the need for integrated infrastructure development on a 
region-wide  basis.  These  publications—Emerging  Asian  Regionalism,  Infrastructure  for  a 
Seamless Asia, and Institutions for Integration: Toward an Asian Economic  Community1—
recognize the importance and benefits of improving regional connectivity to support an effective 
and  efficient  economic  development  that  transcends  borders.  They  also  recognize  that 
significant resources will be required to enhance the connection of the region. Infrastructure for 
a Seamless Asia, for example, estimates that Asia needs $8 trillion in overall infrastructure 
between 2010 and 2020. All three publications unanimously recommend prioritizing key projects 
and identifying alternative forms of financing to address this large infrastructure need. 
 
2.  Recognizing  the  need  for  project  prioritization  and  strong  political  commitment  for 
developing infrastructure in the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) subregion, 
ASEAN leaders endorsed the Master Plan on ASEAN Connectivity (MPAC) in 2010.2 The 
MPAC was developed to help realize an ASEAN Economic Community by 2015. It promotes 
connectivity through enhanced trade, investments, tourism, and people-to-people (including 
labor migration) movements. The MPAC represents an in-depth plan of action based on (i) a list 
of  priority  projects  for  ASEAN  connectivity,  (ii)  requirements  for  institutional  and  policy 
coordination,  and  (iii)  recommendations  for  financing  the  key  projects.  Realizing  the  tasks 
involved,  ASEAN  and  ADB  discussed  a  number  of  initiatives  required  to  support  the 
implementation of the MPAC; the design of this technical assistance (TA) was based on these 
initiatives. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.3 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  In addition to the MPAC, there are a number of other ASEAN initiatives that promote 
infrastructure development, including those that are supported by ADB such as the ASEAN 
Infrastructure Fund (AIF).4 Based on equity investments from ASEAN and ADB, the AIF is 
designed to provide an innovative financing instrument to address the  ASEAN subregion’s 
connectivity constraints. In so doing, the AIF will support the MPAC as a key driver toward 
realizing the vision for an ASEAN Economic Community by 2015. The efforts for infrastructure 
financing  are  combined  with  the  ―software‖  aspects  of  connectivity:  customs,  immigration, 
quarantine and security, and trade facilitation. While these initiatives provide additional support 
to realize the MPAC, other forms of due diligence support will be required to complement them:

2   
(i)  Resource mobilization. Inadequate project finance is an issue highlighted in the 
MPAC.  Because  there  are  limitations  in  public  and  official  development 
assistance financing, it is essential to mobilize additional resources from other 
development partners, the private sector, and the capital market. For example, 
capital  market  financing  needs  to  be  developed  to  support  the  issuance  of 
relevant instruments (such as infrastructure bonds), which are considered to 
have investment grade credit rating. These can be anchored in the AIF and 
complement it. 
 
(ii)  Pipeline  development  and  due  diligence.  Given  the  priority  infrastructure 
projects, sector and project assessments are required to ensure project viability, 
commitment to best practices of governance, and compliance with environmental 
and  social  soundness.  The  comprehensive  assessment  of  key  risks  and 
mitigating measures are, likewise, necessary to develop a robust priority project 
pipeline. Consideration of these issues and early conduct of due diligence will 
help catalyze financing for key projects. Finally, this process should consider 
measures  to  attract  private  investments  through  public–private  partnerships 
(PPPs) and other modalities, as appropriate. 
 
(iii)  Consensus-building  activities.  A  series  of dialogues  and  consultations  are 
needed to ensure that all relevant stakeholders participate. A broad development 
partnership needs to be formed to maximize collective knowledge support and 
coordinated action based on comparative advantage. This requires considerable 
administrative and knowledge development efforts from institutions like ADB. 
 
4.  Individual ASEAN member countries are committed to implementing the MPAC. Further, 
MPAC’s  priority  projects  are  synchronized  and  consistent  with  national  priorities  and 
development  plans,  as  well  as  ADB’s  country  programming  processes.  However,  ASEAN 
member countries need support because of the high financial requirements of projects. While 
the ASEAN member countries established the AIF to mobilize necessary financing on a regional 
basis, additional support will be needed to ensure wider coordination among development 
partners  along  with  the  development  of  a  robust  project  pipeline  and  to  identify  ways  of 
enhancing participation between PPPs and the private sector. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
5.  The impact will be improved connectivity in the ASEAN subregion by supporting the 
implementation of the MPAC, especially by establishing a development partnership mechanism. 
This  is  based  on  the  recognition  that  a  wider  coordination  is  required  because  no  single 
development partner can sufficiently assume the task of supporting the ASEAN connectivity 
and/or  MPAC  implementation.  The  partnership  mechanism  will  build  on  recent  ASEAN 
initiatives, including the AIF, as well as initiatives from other development partners so that ADB 
can more fully leverage the operational expertise and development knowledge. 
 
6.  The  outcome  will  be  the  enhanced  coordination  among  development  partners  in 
mobilizing financing for ASEAN’s infrastructure development through MPAC implementation, 
based on the effective implementation of the AIF and other relevant initiatives. This will be 
based  on  a  sound  project  development  process  and  consensus-building  approach  for

3 
infrastructure development not only between ADB and developing member countries, but also 
with other key development agencies as well as the private sector. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
7.  The TA will be monitored through periodic reports, consensus-building activities and 
workshops,  and  feedback  obtained  through  regular  consultations  with  key  stakeholders.  A 
series of smaller seminars can also be held in coordination with government agencies and other 
ADB departments. Knowledge-sharing and dissemination activities will be carried out to discuss 
results,  good  practices,  and  lessons.  Available  updates,  results,  or  observations  will  be 
discussed and shared in proper forums or reports. Hence, the TA will deliver the following main 
outputs: 
 
(i)  Resource mobilization due diligence, including financial analysis. The TA 
will develop financial models for the relevant ASEAN  infrastructure financing 
initiatives  and  augment  them  with  best  practice  models  of risk management 
frameworks  and  policies  including  liquidity,  cash  management,  and  capital 
adequacy. The analysis will also focus on the use of various capital market 
instruments, especially debt instruments, and identify measures to enhance their 
credit rating and liquidity. These measures will adhere to the existing relevant 
legal frameworks of ASEAN member countries. 
 
(ii)  Project pipeline formulation due diligence. The TA will also provide initial 
screening  of  the  projects  to  be  included  in  the  pipeline  of  ADB  and  other 
development partners and stakeholders. The TA will also produce reports that 
demonstrate the viability of identified key projects. Through this component, the 
TA will identify major issues associated with project preparation and will consult 
with the development partners and other stakeholders to ensure that high priority 
sovereign and nonsovereign projects as listed in the MPAC will have the proper 
initial screening for eventual project preparation. The TA will also consider, in 
coordination with the development partners and stakeholders, projects not listed 
in the MPAC but that are expected to contribute toward enhanced connectivity 
(which may include software infrastructure).5 
 
(iii)  Stakeholder  consultation  process  for  consensus  building.  Considerable 
efforts are needed to provide operational and knowledge support to ASEAN 
members on the relevant projects and programs.  A coordinated approach is 
required since no single agency can sufficiently provide financing for all of the 
MPAC priority projects. Accordingly, the TA will facilitate consensus among the 
development partners and stakeholders. Based on this approach, consensus 
needs to be achieved on the priority projects, policy implications, and financing 
mechanisms.  It  will  also  be  important  to  ascertain  support  from  the  key 
development  partners  to  identify  additional  support  for  various,  relevant 
initiatives, including the AIF. 6 
                                                
5  This output will also consider PPPs and measures to attract private investments through other modalities. The TA 
will identify appropriate, potential projects that could be financed by ADB and AIF, under the PPP modality. This will 
identify and seek links with the ongoing initiatives at both regional and national levels. Linked with the financial 
analysis component, the use of capital market instruments to support infrastructure financing will also be analyzed.  
6  For this TA project, the development partners include relevant ASEAN members, ADB, and relevant agencies in 
Japan (as the region’s key provider of development assistance and this TA). Additional partners can be identified in 
coordination with the current partners and other stakeholders.

4   
 
8.  The assumptions and risks on developing the TA with the above components have been 
considered. The assumptions are (i) regional cooperation and integration will continue to be 
recognized by the ASEAN developing member countries as important for enhancing economic 
growth  and  reducing  poverty;  (ii)  based  on  the  consensus-building  approach,  the  national 
policies will be geared towards harnessing the full benefits of regional infrastructure integration; 
and (iii) cooperation between ADB and key stakeholders (including those outside ASEAN) will 
be ensured. The risks include (i) a global economic downturn that could lead to a policy shift 
toward more urgent domestic economic and social concerns rather than the implementation of 
regional cooperation and integration initiatives; (ii) a lack of active participation by some ASEAN 
members that could hamper efforts to forge an ASEAN consensus on the key issues; and (iii) 
the TA project’s ability to produce timely high-quality outputs that are key to decision-making 
and consensus-building among the various development partners. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
9.  The TA is estimated to cost $975,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed on a grant 
basis by the Japan–ASEAN Integration Fund.7 The cost estimates and financing plan are in 
Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
10.  ADB will be the executing agency. The TA will be implemented from 1 January to 31 
December 2012 by the Regional Cooperation and Operations Coordination Division (SERC), 
Southeast Asia Department, with support from other ADB departments. SERC will coordinate 
with sector divisions and resident missions on TA findings regarding project pipeline and PPP 
project identification. ADB will seek coordination with ASEAN and its initiatives, including the 
AIF.  In  addition,  as  part  of  the  development  partners’  coordination,  various  stakeholders, 
including agencies from Japan, will be consulted on the key findings to identify key strategic 
areas of mutual cooperation. Based on this, additional development partners, both within and 
outside the ASEAN subregion, will also be consulted. SERC will assign one or two international 
staff  to  supervise  the  overall  implementation  of  the  TA,  with  support  from  national  and 
administrative staff. In addition, SERC will form an interdepartmental team of experts to support 
the TA implementation. Key officials from ASEAN and other development partners will also 
provide input to the TA operations. 
 
11.  A group of individual consultants (and firms as appropriate8) will provide the advisory, 
technical,  and  administrative  support  services.  It  is  estimated  that  26  person-months  of 
international  consulting services  and  25  person-months  of  national  consulting services  are 
required for the TA. Due to the diverse skills requirements, consultants will be engaged on an 
individual basis or through a firm per given component in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on 
the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). The outline terms of reference for 
consultants are in Appendix 3. A team of SERC staff members, in coordination with other ADB 
departments, will review the outputs. 
 
12.  The purchase of equipment (computer hardware and software) will be carried out in 
accordance with ADB's Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time) and in

Administrative Services, where applicable. After the TA completion, any procured equipment will 
be disposed of in compliance with the project administration instructions.9 Disbursements under 
the TA will be made in accordance with ADB's Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook 
(2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
13.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $975,000 to be financed on a 
grant basis by the Japan–ASEAN Integration Fund for the Master Plan on ASEAN Connectivity 
Implementation, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The terms of reference (TOR) stipulate that the work plan is subject to refinement by the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB). The work plan of the national consultants may also be refined, 
based on the needs of the international consultants and ADB. Further, all team members are 
requested to assist ADB with the related activities and engage in consultations with the relevant 
stakeholders, as appropriate. Consulting services may be provided intermittently, based on 
agreement between the consultants and ADB. 
 
A.  Team Leader and Infrastructure Financing Specialist (international, 6 person-months) 
 
2.  The specialist will support ADB for the overall outputs of the technical assistance (TA). 
He or she will also support ADB to oversee the work of the other consultants and recommend 
adjustments in the team's work program, as required. He or she will also support ADB on 
various administration and activities of the TA, including the necessary procurements for the TA. 
The specialist's tasks will include, but not necessarily be limited to, the following: 
(i)  during the inception phase of the TA, draft a time-bound work program for the 
other members of the TA for the review of ADB; 
(ii)  develop a detailed report to provide priority implementation requirements for the 
Master  Plan  on  ASEAN  Connectivity  implementation,  including  the  various 
financial schemes (e.g., the ASEAN Infrastructure Fund [AIF]); 
(iii)  support ADB internal coordination to ensure that a robust project pipeline is in 
place for the Master Plan on ASEAN Connectivity implementation; 
(iv)  complete a series of knowledge products based on the above components and 
disseminate them appropriately to the stakeholders; 
(v)  engage in workshops and dissemination activities to build consensus among 
stakeholders on priority objectives ; and 
(vi)  support ADB, in coordination with the development partners, in other activities 
relevant to regional infrastructure development. 
 
3.  The  specialist  should  have  extensive  experience  in  developing,  evaluating,  and 
delivering regional infrastructure projects. He or she should have at least 15 years of experience 
in regional infrastructure development, preferably in Asia; a degree in engineering, economics, 
or related fields is preferred. 
 
B.  Financial Specialist (international, 4 person-months) 
 
4.  The specialist will support ADB for the TA's overall outputs through close collaboration 
with the team leader. The specialist's tasks will include, but not necessarily be limited to, the 
following: 
(i)  develop  a  detailed  financial  model  for  the  initiatives  (including  the  AIF)  and 
augment them based on best practice models of risk management framework 
and policies including liquidity, cash management, and capital adequacy; 
(ii)  provide  a  set  of  detailed  recommendations  that  focus  on  the  use  of  debt 
instruments for infrastructure financing and identify measures to enhance their 
credit rating and liquidity; these measures will adhere to the legal frameworks of 
the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) member countries; 
(iii)  complete a series of knowledge products based on the above components and 
disseminate them appropriately to the stakeholders; 
(iv)  engage in workshops and dissemination activities to build consensus for the 
relevant stakeholders; and

(v)  support ADB, in coordination with the development partners, in other activities 
relevant to regional infrastructure development. 
 
5.  The  specialist  should  have  extensive  experience  in  developing,  evaluating,  and 
delivering  infrastructure  financing  initiatives.  He  or  she  should  have  at  least  15  years  of 
experience in finance, preferably in Asia; a degree in finance or related fields is preferred. 
 
C.  Credit Rating Specialist (international, 4 person-months) 
 
6.  The specialist will support ADB for the TA's overall outputs through close collaboration 
with the team leader. The consultant's tasks will include, but not necessarily be limited to, the 
following: 
(i)  conduct a detailed analysis of ASEAN’s infrastructure financing schemes and 
provide  a  detailed  set  of  recommendations  to  enhance  the  credit  rating  of 
initiatives and debt instruments; 
(ii)  develop an action plan and presentation materials for ADB’s consultations with 
the credit rating agencies; 
(iii)  analyze the relevant regulations on the region’s foreign exchange reserves to 
understand the investment guidelines and reserve eligibility; 
(iv)  complete a series of knowledge products based on the above components and 
disseminate them appropriately to the stakeholders; 
(v)  engage in workshops and dissemination activities to build consensus for the 
relevant stakeholders; and 
(vi)  support ADB, in coordination with the development partners, in other activities 
relevant to regional infrastructure development. 
 
7.  The  specialist  should  have  extensive  experience  in  developing,  evaluating,  and 
delivering credit rating advisory and analysis. He or she should have at least 10 years of 
experience in a relevant field, preferably in Asia; a degree in finance is preferred. 
 
D.  Project Pipeline Development Specialists (international, 8 person-months) 
 
8.  A group of individual specialists will be recruited to conduct about five studies on the key 
projects for the purpose of pipeline formulation; a full set of feasibility studies is expected when 
the projects are selected to be financed. The group will receive feedback and guidance from 
ADB and other development partners. They will be further supported by the national group of 
consultants. A detailed TOR will be drafted based on the TA progress and recommendations 
from the sector divisions within ADB’s Southeast Asia Department. The studies to be carried out 
will  include  detailed  analysis,  including  of  the  engineering  design  of  the  projects.  Other 
components include (i) economic and financial analyses; (ii) analyses on safeguard issues 
(resettlement, indigenous peoples, and the environment); and (iii) poverty and social impact 
analyses,  including  gender  assessments.  Most  of  the  work  will  be  in  the  field,  and  the 
prefeasibility  studies  group  will  comprise  the  following:  (i)  transport  specialists/road/railway 
engineers, (ii) a financial specialist, (iii) a social and/or gender specialist, and (iv) a safeguard 
specialist. 
 
E.  Legal Specialist (international, 1 person-month) 
 
9.  The specialist will support ADB for the TA's overall outputs through close collaboration 
with the team leader. The specialist's tasks will include, but not necessarily be limited to, the 
following:

(i)  review  and  provide  recommendations  on  the  relevant  legal  frameworks  for 
ASEAN,  specifically  as  related  to  establishing  a  legal  entity  to  engage  in 
infrastructure financing; 
(ii)  develop a set of relevant legal guidelines for ASEAN initiatives (including the AIF) 
to support infrastructure financing; 
(iii)  complete a series of knowledge products based on the above components and 
disseminate them appropriately to the stakeholders; 
(iv)  engage in workshops and dissemination activities to build consensus for the 
relevant stakeholders; and 
(v)  support ADB, in coordination with the development partners, in other activities 
relevant to regional infrastructure development. 
 
10.  The  consultant  should  have  extensive  experience  in  developing,  evaluating,  and 
delivering inputs on commercial legal frameworks. He or she should have at least 10 years of 
experience in a relevant field; a degree in law is required. 
 
F.  Public–Private Partnership Specialist (international, 3 person-months) 
 
11.  The specialist will support ADB for the TA's overall outputs through close collaboration 
with the team leader. The specialist's tasks will include, but not necessarily be limited to, the 
following: 
(i)  based on the relevant documents (ADB’s plans for public–private partnership 
[PPP] promotion, among others), develop a detailed action plan to enhance PPP 
financing in the ASEAN region; 
(ii)  conduct an analysis on the market conditions relevant to the proposed work, 
including the activities and experiences of the comparator entities; 
(iii)  conduct  an  analysis  to  identify  a  set  of  viable  options  for  ADB  and  other 
development partners for this work, including the resource and administrative 
requirements; 
(iv)  engage in workshops and dissemination activities to build consensus for the 
relevant stakeholders; and 
(v)  support ADB, in coordination with the development partners, in other activities 
relevant to the regional infrastructure development. 
 
12.  The  specialist  should  have  extensive  experience  in  developing,  evaluating,  and 
delivering inputs on commercial legal frameworks. He or she should have at least 10 years of 
experience in a relevant field; a degree in law is preferred. 
 
G.  National Consultants (25 person-months in total) 
 
13.  A group of individual consultants will be recruited to provide technical and administrative 
support to the TA, under the guidance of the international  consultants. The specific tasks 
include 
(i)  collect and analyze required information and data, in an organized form, and 
conduct research on specific topics; 
(ii)  undertake overall administrative and organizational aspects of the TA team's 
operations; 
(iii)  help the international consultants with their tasks; and 
(iv)  arrange and organize discussions and workshops, and assist the international 
consultants in preparing materials for them.

12  Appendix 3 
 
 
14.  Specifically, national consultants will be recruited for the following positions: (i) a regional 
infrastructure specialist and/or coordinator (7 person-months), (ii) a financial analyst (4 person-
months), (iii) a group of project pipeline development specialists (8 person-months in total), (iv) 
an economic or copy editor (3 person-months), and (v) a PPP specialist (3 person-months). 
 
15.  The  consultants  should  have  extensive  experience  in  developing,  evaluating,  and 
delivering  regional transport projects. They  should  have  at  least  5  years  of  experience  in 
economics or finance, preferably in Asia; a degree in infrastructure, economics, or related fields 
is preferred. 
 
H.  Reporting Requirements 
 
16.  The consultants will submit the following reports:1 
(i)  Inception report (1 month after the TA’s inception), presenting the initial findings 
and describing the operational approach and the work program. This exercise will 
be led mostly by the team leader, based on his or her TOR. 
(ii)  First interim report (3 months after the TA’s inception), presenting the preliminary 
findings and recommendations, and proposing modifications, if any, to the TA 
activities during the remaining period. 
(iii)  Second interim report (6 months after the TA’s inception) and third interim report 
(9  months  after  the  TA’s  inception),  presenting  detailed  findings  and 
recommendations, including the detailed implementation arrangements. 
(iv)  Final report  (12  months  after  the  TA’s  inception),  incorporating  comments 
received  on  the  draft  final  report.  Additional  output  requirements  will  be 
determined based on the need and the TA progress. 
 
                                                
1  In addition, as the TA is funded by the Japan–ASEAN Integration Fund (JAIF), the following reporting requirement 
will also apply: A semiannual financial report and project completion report with the relevant information (including 
disbursement information) will be submitted to the ASEAN Secretariat, JAIF coordinator, and the relevant agencies 
in Japan. It was also understood that any remaining fund from the TA will be returned within 90 days of the TA 
completion.
